Hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes is an important reaction for synthesizing aldehydes; however, traditional low-cost Ni catalysts exhibit low hydrogenation activity primarily due to their poor hydrogen activation ability. In this study, we introduced Pt single atoms dispersed in Ni particles to form a PtNi/SiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation of methyl acrylaldehyde to isobutyraldehyde. The incorporation of Pt single atoms increased the activity of PtNi/SiO2 by more than four times compared to Ni/SiO2, while maintaining 100% selectivity for the hydrogenation of the C = C double bond. A series of characterization results and DFT calculation demonstrated that Pt doping enhanced H2 dissociation and hydrogen spillover compared to the limited hydrogen activation observed on Ni/SiO2. Furthermore, the Pt single atoms exhibited a stronger electronic transfer effect with Ni, which enhanced the ability of the Pt single atoms to activate H2 and facilitate hydrogen spillover, thereby resulting in improved catalytic activity of the catalyst. This study emphasized the advantages and synergistic effects of single atoms in enhancing the catalytic activity of bimetallic catalyst systems. This reaction has garnered extensive attention in both fundamental research and industrial applications. Given the presence of both C = C and C = O conjugated active functional groups in α,β-unsaturated aldehyde molecules, achieving precise and efficient selective hydrogenation of C = C, despite its thermodynamic favorability for hydrogenation, remains a significant challenge [5,6]. Thermodynamic factors suggest that low-temperature conditions can enhance the selectivity for the hydrogenation of C = C double bonds; however, non-precious metal catalysts, favored for their cost-effectiveness in industrial applications, exhibit suboptimal activity under these conditions [7,8]. Therefore, improving catalyst activity while reducing costs is seen as a critical objective for current and future research. Previous studies have demonstrated that, compared to other metals, Ni-based catalysts exhibit a greater propensity to promote the hydrogenation of C = C double bonds, however, their catalytic activity remains relatively low [9–12]. To enhance the activity of Ni-based catalysts, several strategies have been employed, including the optimization of metal-support interactions [13], the development of geometrically confined structures [14,15], and the doping of secondary metals to alter electronic properties [16,17]. Despite these interventions showing improvements in catalytic activity, challenges such as low atomic utilization, high costs, and insufficient stability have hindered satisfactory results. Additionally, an alternative design strategy for developing efficient and stable catalysts involves the dispersion of highly active noble metal single atoms (such as Pt) on the surfaces of less reactive metals [18–22]. However, the specific hydrogen activation mechanisms and synergistic effects of atomically dispersed Pt on Ni-based catalysts remain unclear. Therefore, it is intriguing to elucidate the promotional role of Pt species in the hydrogenation of C = C through scale control from nano to atomic levels. In this paper, we used methacrolein (MAL) as a model compound to achieve selective hydrogenation of the C = C bond in α,β-unsaturated aldehydes. Pt was utilized as the highly active metal for H2 activation [23–25]. By controlling the Pt loading, a catalyst comprising Pt single atoms dispersed on PtNi/SiO2 was prepared. The advantages of Pt single atoms in promoting hydrogenation reactions over Ni particles were investigated. Stronger interactions between the Pt single atoms and Ni were observed, facilitating enhanced electron transfer from Ni to the Pt single atoms. This dynamic endows the Pt single atoms with superior activation and hydrogen spillover capabilities, which are critical for achieving higher catalytic activity. This paper highlights the advantages and synergistic catalytic effects of Pt single atoms in enhancing Ni-based catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals employed in this study were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Nano-sized SiO2 was selected as the support material, while Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Pt(NO3)2 were utilized as metal precursors. The Ni/SiO2 catalyst and the PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings were synthesized using the urea precipitation method, in which urea acted as the precipitating agent. 2.2 Catalyst preparation For the preparation of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, 0.9907 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was initially dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, and the solution was stirred for 15 mins to ensure complete dissolution. Subsequently, 9.8 g of SiO2 solid was added to the mixture, and stirring continued for an additional 15 mins to achieve a uniform dispersion. An excess of urea (10 g) was then introduced to the solution, allowing the mixture to precipitate for 10 h in a water bath maintained at 90 °C. Following centrifugation, the precipitate was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and subsequently cooled to room temperature. The resulting material underwent calcination in air at 500 °C for 4 h, followed by reduction in a hydrogen-argon mixed gas atmosphere at 450 °C for 4 h, ultimately yielding a 2 wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst. The preparation steps for the PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings closely resembled those used for the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. The primary distinction involved the dissolution of the corresponding Pt(NO3)2 solution in 50 mL of deionized water, followed by stirring for 15 mins. Subsequently, 2 wt% Ni/SiO2 was utilized in place of SiO2 and added to the mixed solution, which was stirred for an additional 15 mins. The subsequent steps for catalyst synthesis were consistent with those employed for the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. In this study, catalysts with different Pt and/or Ni loadings are designated as xPtyNi/SiO2, where x and y denote the mass fractions of Pt and Ni, respectively. Additionally, a monometallic Pt/SiO2 catalyst was prepared using the impregnation method for comparative purposes, with a Pt mass fraction of 0.5%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of the catalysts were analyzed using an X'Pert PRO MPD-type X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα ray source and a detection range of 2θ = 10 - 90°.A JEOL JSM-2010 transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to define the size and distribution state of the Pt and Ni metal on the surface of the catalyst. The binding energy and different valence content of each element on the surface of the catalyst were determined by a Perkin-Elmer PHI ESCA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. An Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorption device was employed for the H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) to evaluate the properties of adsorbed hydrogen properties of the loaded metals on the surface of the catalyst. The H2-TPR characterization process involves initially heating 0.1 g of the catalyst from room temperature to 300 °C, followed by a 1 hour nitrogen purge to remove surface impurities. Subsequently, the temperature is lowered to 50 °C, and the sample is subjected to a heating ramp in a 10% H2-Ar mixture up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, with gas evolution monitored using TCD. For the H2-TPD characterization, 0.1 g of the catalyst is heated to 300 °C and reduced in hydrogen for 1 hour. Afterward, the same temperature is maintained while purging with argon for 0.5 h. The sample is then cooled to 50 °C, where it is exposed to a 10% H2-Ar mixture to achieve saturation adsorption. Following this, the argon purge is applied for 1 hour, and the sample is subsequently heated in argon at a rate of 10 °C/min up to 800 °C, with the evolved gases again detected using TCD. Additionally, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy of CO was performed with a Thermo Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. The catalyst was initially subjected to hydrogen reduction at 350 °C for 1 hour to ensure that the metal was in its reduced state. Subsequently, the sample was purged with He to facilitate cooling, and CO was introduced at room temperature for adsorption. Following CO saturation, the sample was cleaned with He, and spectral data were continuously recorded. 2.4 DFT calculations DFT calculations were successfully completed utilizing the DMol3 module of Materials Studio 2019 software. To describe the correlation energies, the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional were used. For electron treatment, the double-numeric polarized basis set (DNP) was chosen along with the effective core potentials (ECP) method. Additionally, the 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack value was adopted for sampling the Brillouin zone. To ensure the high precision of the calculation results, permissible convergence value for gradient, displacement and total energy are 0.002 Ha/Ǻ, 0.005 Ǻ and 1.0 × 10–5 Ha, respectively. The LST/QST method was employed suitably to search for transition states, and the validity of these states was subsequently verified through frequency calculations and transition state optimization. For the computational models, the Ni(111) surface was constructed to four layers (3 × 3 × 4) with 36 atoms in the 15 Å vacuum layer, of which the two bottom layers were fixed, while the two top layers were relaxed during the calculation. All the energies were corrected by ZPE. 2.5 Catalytic tests The catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts was assessed in a 50 mL stainless steel high-pressure reactor. Specifically, a mixture of 25 mL of MAL and ethanol (1 mol/L, with ethanol serving as the solvent) was combined with 0.3 g of the catalyst and placed within a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) liner. The reactor was purged five times with pure hydrogen gas to eliminate any residual gases. Following this, hydrogen gas was introduced into the reactor at the desired reaction pressure. The reaction was conducted under predetermined pressure and temperature conditions, with a stirring speed set at 1000 RPM. The diffraction peaks of all catalysts corresponded to the hexagonal crystal structure of SiO2 (PDF#85–0796). This absence of observable peaks is primarily attributed to the low metal loadings (Pt: 0.1–1.0 wt%; Ni: 2 wt%), which resulted in weak characteristic peaks that were overshadowed by the strong peaks of the SiO2 support [5,29]. Subsequently, to further investigate the surface structure and metal particle distribution of PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings, characterization was conducted using TEM and HRTEM. Under different Pt loading conditions, Ni was observed to disperse in the form of metal clusters on the catalyst surface. TEM was employed to measure the particle size distribution of the Ni clusters across different catalysts, revealing sizes between 7 and 10 nm, as shown in Figs. 1b and S2. The incorporation of Pt significantly reduced the particle size of the catalysts compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, and this effect became more pronounced with increasing Pt loading. It was widely recognized that a reduction in the particle size of Ni on Ni-based catalysts enhanced H2 activation, thereby improving catalytic activity during hydrogenation reactions [30–32]. However, experimental results from this study indicated that as the loading of Pt increased, the particle size of Ni decreased, leading to a trend of initially increased catalytic activity followed by a decline (Table S1). This finding suggested that the variation in the scale of Pt species had a more pronounced effect on catalyst activity. Additionally, the lattice spacings of different catalysts were measured from the HRTEM images. At lower Pt loadings (less than 0.5 wt%), a lattice spacing of 0.204 nm was obtained, corresponding to the Ni (111) plane, with no observation of the Pt (111) plane. It was inferred that Pt might have been atomically dispersed at this loading level. With an increase in Pt loading, a lattice spacing of 0.215 nm was detected, attributed to the Pt (111) plane [33–35]. Furthermore, on the surface of the 1.0Pt2Ni/SiO2 catalyst, Pt metal particles were observed, with sizes ranging from 1 to 3 nm (Figure S3). This observation indicated that a higher Pt loading resulted in the formation of larger Pt clusters on the catalyst surface. The EDX mapping images of PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings were presented in Figure S4. At lower Pt loadings, Pt was uniformly dispersed, and no significant agglomeration was observed (Figure S4a). However, as the Pt loading increased, clusters of Pt gradually formed on the catalyst surface(Figure S4c). This result further confirmed that the scale of Pt species on the catalyst surface changed with increasing Pt loading. To better determine the dispersion state of Pt on Ni at varying loadings, CO was utilized as a probe molecule for in situ infrared spectroscopy. This method provided comprehensive information to identify the Pt configurations within the PtNi catalyst on the surface. The in situ infrared spectra of CO for different Pt loadings are presented in Fig. 1d. For the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, prolonged He purging led to the gradual disappearance of gas-phase CO peaks at 2116 cm⁻¹ and 2170 cm⁻¹, ultimately approaching a straight line in the 1800–2250 cm⁻¹ range (Figure S5) [36]. In the case of the 0.3Pt2Ni/SiO2 catalyst, after extended purging, a peak centered at 2060 cm⁻¹ was observed, attributed to linear adsorption of CO on Pt0 (Figure S6) [37,38]. When the Pt loading was increased to 1.0%, peaks centered at 1870 cm⁻¹ and 1982 cm⁻¹ were observed after purging, indicating bridge adsorption of CO (Figure S7) [38,39]. The in-situ infrared results of CO demonstrated that the PtNi/SiO2 catalyst with Pt single atoms dispersion was successfully prepared by regulating the loading amount of Pt [36,40,41]. 3.2 Impact of pd-doping on hydrogen activation To explore the mutual influence between Pt and Ni, we characterized the surface electronic properties and chemical states of the catalyst by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 2 a presents the XPS spectra of the Pt4f region for PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings, as well as for pure Pt/SiO2 catalysts. It is observed that Pt predominantly exists in the form of Pt0, indicating that the Pt2+ precursor has been successfully reduced to metallic Pt on the catalyst surface. In the PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with different Pt loadings, a new strong peak is observed at a binding energy of 68.0 eV, which can be attributed to the Ni3p XPS signal [33,42,43]. This finding suggests a significant interaction between Pt and Ni. Furthermore, compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, the Pt4f peaks in the PtNi/SiO2 catalysts exhibit a negative shift. Previous studies have indicated that this negative shift in the Pt4f peak for PtNi/SiO2 catalysts may result from electron migration from Ni to Pt [44]. Such electron transfer can cause a downward shift in the center position of the Pt d-band, facilitating the adsorption and activation of reactants on the catalyst surface, thereby enhancing catalytic activity [25,44–46]. When Pt is dispersed as single atoms, stronger interactions between Pt and Ni are observed, leading to a more pronounced negative shift. The Ni2p spectrum for the PtNi/SiO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 2b, where it is evident that Ni predominantly exists as Ni2+ in both Ni/SiO2 and PtNi/SiO2 [47]. This may be attributed to strong interactions between Ni and the SiO2 support. In the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, a peak corresponding to Ni0 is present in addition to Ni2+, but this Ni0 peak disappears upon the introduction of Pt. This phenomenon may be related to the electron transfer between Pt and Ni. To demonstrate the promotional effect of Pt on hydrogen activation on Ni, H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) analyses were conducted. The H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 2c. For the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, diffraction peaks were observed at 358 °C and 460 °C. The peak at 358 °C corresponds to the reduction of NiO, while the broad diffraction peak around 460 °C arises from the high dispersion of NiO, which is influenced by strong interactions between certain NiO and the SiO2 support [48,49]. In the PtNi/SiO2 catalyst, the addition of Pt resulted in varying degrees of shifts of the NiO reduction peaks toward lower temperatures. The decrease in the NiO reduction temperature can be attributed to the dissociation of H2 on Pt, leading to the generation of activated hydrogen that spills over to the relatively inert NiO, thereby facilitating the reduction of NiO to its metallic state [24]. This observation also confirms the presence of hydrogen spillover on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, when Pt is dispersed as single atoms, the reduction temperature of NiO is minimized (323 °C), and the proportion of the high-temperature reduction peak is the smallest, indicating that Pt single atoms is more favorable for the reduction of NiO. Compared to Pt clusters, Pt single atoms exhibits stronger electron transfer with Ni particles, facilitating the activation and spillover of H2 on Pt single atoms, which in turn promotes NiO reduction. The adsorption behavior of H2 on the catalyst surface was investigated using H2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (H2-TPD), with results presented in Fig. 2d. For the monometallic Pt/SiO2 catalyst, no significant H2 desorption peaks were observed in the H2-TPD curve (Figure S8), which can be attributed to the weak adsorption of H2 on the Pt surface, allowing the adsorbed hydrogen to quickly desorb at low temperatures [50,51]. In contrast, the H2-TPD curves for both Ni/SiO2 and PtNi/SiO2 catalysts exhibited three desorption peaks, approximately at 100 °C, 400–500 °C, and 550–600 °C. The low-temperature H2 desorption peak at around 100 °C is attributed to hydrogen desorbing from the surface of Ni. In contrast, the high-temperature desorption peaks at 300–500 °C and 500–600 °C are attributed to the desorption of H2 from the metal-support interface and the spillover of H, respectively [24,51,52]. Additionally, the incorporation of Pt effectively lowered the high-temperature H2 desorption temperature on the catalyst surface, indicating that the presence of Pt significantly enhances the catalyst's ability to desorb hydrogen. When Pt is dispersed as single atoms (0.3Pt2Ni/SiO2), the high-temperature hydrogen desorption peaks were recorded at the lowest temperatures (400 °C and 552 °C). As the Pt loading increased, the distribution of Pt transitioned from single atoms to clusters on the Ni particles, resulting in a shift of the hydrogen desorption peaks to higher temperatures. This suggests that Pt single atoms is more effective in promoting H2 desorption. The characterization results from XPS, H2-TPD, and H2-TPR indicate that a stronger electronic transfer effect exist between the Pt single atoms and Ni particles. This enhanced interaction facilitates H2 activation and hydrogen spillover. 3.3 Catalyst performance evaluation A series of PtNi/SiO2 catalysts were evaluated for their performance in the hydrogenation of MAL using a batch reactor. The results of the reactions conducted at 80 °C and 1.5 MPa for 3 h are presented in Fig. 3 a and Table S1. For the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, the selectivity towards isobutyraldehyde after MAL hydrogenation approached 100%; however, the catalyst exhibited poor activity, with a MAL conversion rate of only 22.18%. The incorporation of Pt significantly enhanced the catalytic activity without compromising the selectivity for C = C hydrogenation. Furthermore, the monometallic Pt/SiO2 catalyst did not undergo hydrogenation reactions. To clarify the activity of catalysts with varying Pt loadings, the turnover frequency (TOF) at 80 °C was calculated, as shown in Fig. 3b and Table S2. The 0.3Pt2Ni/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated the optimal catalytic performance (TOF = 538.13 h-1), outperforming both the Ni/SiO2 catalyst (TOF = 159.44 h-1) and other Pt-loaded PtNi/SiO2 catalysts. An increase in Pt loading led to a decrease in catalyst activity. This reduction may be attributed to the transformation of Pt configurations on the catalyst surface from isolated atoms to clusters, which adversely affects H2 activation and hydrogen release. The reaction activation energies for the different catalysts were determined experimentally, as illustrated in Fig. 3c and Table S3, revealing that the 0.3Pt2Ni/SiO2 catalyst had the lowest activation energy (16.64 kJ/mol), consistent with the observed experimental phenomena. Additionally, the stability of the 0.3Pt2Ni/SiO2 catalyst was assessed (Fig. 3d), and no significant decrease in activity was observed after five cycles, indicating excellent stability of the catalyst. 3.3 DFT calculation of H2 activation and spillover for different pt configurations To further illustrate the superiority of Pt single atoms in catalytic hydrogenation reactions, in conjunction with the outcomes of catalyst characterization, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed regarding the activation and spillover of hydrogen on Pt single atoms as well as Pt clusters. The promotion of hydrogen activation by Pt was divided into two consecutive steps: the dissociation of hydrogen and the spillover of hydrogen atoms [24]. The detailed configurations of H2 and/or H atoms on the catalyst surfaces were illustrated in Figs. 4 a and 4b. In the first step, concerning the activation of H2, the energy barrier for H2 dissociation on Pt single atoms supported on Ni was notably low (approximately 0 eV). Upon adsorption, H2 spontaneously dissociated into two H atoms (from Fig. 4a-1 to 4a-2). In contrast, the dissociation energy barrier for H₂ on Pt clusters was 0.06 eV (from Fig. 4b-1 to 4b-2), which was higher than that on the Pt single atoms. The next step involved the spillover of activated H atoms from Pt to Ni. The energy barrier for H spillover from a Pt single atom on Ni was 0.22 eV (from Fig. 4a-2 to 4a-3), whereas the spillover barrier on Pt clusters was 0.58 eV (from Fig. 4b-2 to 4b-3), significantly exceeding that of the Pt single atoms. In summary, the presence of Pt in different dispersion states on Ni demonstrated that Pt single atoms were more advantageous for the activation and dissociation of H2. Based on a series of characterization results, it was further demonstrated that the presence of Pt single atoms was more favorable for H2 activation and spillover, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. The results obtained from DFT calculations were consistent with the characterization and experimental findings. Based on a series of characterization and experimental results, a hydrogenation reaction model for MAL on PtNi/SiO2 catalysts was proposed (Fig. 4c). Previous studies indicated that the activation of hydrogen was the rate-determining step in the hydrogenation reaction [3,53,54]. The experimental and characterization results demonstrated that the incorporation of Pt significantly enhanced H2 activation and spillover, thereby improving catalytic activity. However, the absence of catalytic activity in Pt/SiO2 suggested that Pt, when supported on the metallic Ni particles, acted primarily as an H2 activation site. The conjugated C = C moiety in MAL adsorbed onto the Ni particle surface through (π-complex) and (di-σ, η2(C = C)) modes [25,55]. Furthermore, the Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibited some hydrogenation activity, indicating that Ni particles not only provided adsorption sites for MAL but also facilitated the slow activation of H2. After the doping of Pt, H2 was rapidly activated on the Pt species and subsequently migrated to the Ni particles, where it underwent hydrogenation with the adsorbed C = C. The presence of Pt atoms on the Ni particles enhanced the capacity for H2 activation and spillover, resulting in increased catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion Different PtNi/SiO2 catalysts with varying Pt loadings were prepared to achieve distinct dispersions of Pt single atoms and Pt clusters. The introduction of Pt significantly enhanced the catalytic activity compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. As the Pt loading increased, the Pt species transitioned from single atoms to clusters on the catalyst surface. A series of characterization results demonstrated that stronger electronic transfer occurred between the Pt single atoms and Ni, which facilitated the activation and spillover of H2 on the Pt single atoms, ultimately resulting in higher catalytic activity. Additionally, based on the characterization and reaction results, a hydrogenation reaction model for MAL on the PtNi/SiO2 catalyst was proposed. In this model, H2 was activated more rapidly on the Pt single atoms and spilled over to the surface of Ni particles, where it reacted with MAL adsorbed on the Ni particles. This study highlighted the advantages and synergistic effects of single atoms in enhancing catalytic activity within bimetallic catalyst systems, providing valuable insights for the industrial design of highly active bimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes is an important reaction for synthesizing aldehydes; however, traditional low-cost Ni catalysts exhibit low hydrogenation activity primarily due to their poor hydrogen activation ability. In this study, we introduced Pt single atoms dispersed in Ni particles to form a PtNi/SiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation of methyl acrylaldehyde to isobutyraldehyde. The incorporation of Pt single atoms increased the activity of PtNi/SiO2 by more than four times compared to Ni/SiO2, while maintaining 100% selectivity for the hydrogenation of the C = C double bond. A series of characterization results and DFT calculation demonstrated that Pt doping enhanced H2 dissociation and hydrogen spillover compared to the limited hydrogen activation observed on Ni/SiO2. Furthermore, the Pt single atoms exhibited a stronger electronic transfer effect with Ni, which enhanced the ability of the Pt single atoms to activate H2 and facilitate hydrogen spillover, thereby resulting in improved catalytic activity of the catalyst. This study emphasized the advantages and synergistic effects of single atoms in enhancing the catalytic activity of bimetallic catalyst systems.
